title: VGC11 Offensive Power Rankings: Coverage Move Types
description: Let's measure coverage effectiveness for each type and evaluate the current VGC11 meta.
contents:
Offensive Power Rankings: Which move type is most effective into the meta?
This is probably a simple question to answer for experts, so why even bother with data? I can think of a few reason
To answer this question, we need a data definition of the meta. We will use two:
All functional Pokemon in the meta. This will serve as a good baseline and in the absence of data such as usage statistics can be a good starting point. Functional is the key word here as we will only consider fully evolved Pokemon and common eviolite mons such as Porygon2, Dusclops, etc.
Usage-adjusted Pokemon. We will also compute statistics using usage statistics as weights. As a simple example, imagine taking the average HP of every functional Pokemon (it’s 82). However, weighted averages give more weight based on usage, so it is sum(HP*usage)/sum(usage). No insight here but this principle will be important.
Let’s dive in and look at our current meta: VGC 2021 Season 11, per Pikalytics:
So what move typings provide the most effective coverage into this meta? For this I joined the types to these mons and aggregate by type combinations. Now we create a dataset of every possible attack type (barring Flying Press) combined with every monotype and dual type and average the effectiveness over the attacks. This gives us our average attack effectiveness.

What conclusions can we draw from this:
Ground, Rock, and Ice provide the best offensive coverage
Fire, Steel, and Psychic drop significantly when we adjust our metrics for the current meta, though Fire is by no means bad

title: Welcome to Pokemon Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability
description: What can data teach us about Pokemon?
contents:
This blog is about statistics, probability, and data analysis in Pokemon. I’ll publish when I have something to say.
A little about me:
I’m not that good at Pokemon. Getting into VGC but only in the last month or so. I’ve played casually off and on for many years but I barely know the type chart. I do not care at all about PoGo or the TCG or the anime. I like all the video games and have no hot takes.
I don’t believe data analysis has all the answers. It may not even be all that useful for expert players. I’ve seen lots of bad data analysis on Pokemon that reinforces my belief that data science is a puerile discipline. I’ll probably do my fair share of that as well. However, I do think data analysis can help beginners like me climb the learning curve faster.
